Settled by French Huguenot settlers, it was named, along with the county, for the French town of the same name.
Founded in 1835, Aiken was named after William Aiken, the president of the South Carolina Railroad.
According to 2020 census, the population was 32025, making it the 15th-most populous city in South Carolina, and one of the two largest cities of the Central Savannah River Area.

Over the years Aiken became a winter home for many notable people, including George H. Bostwick, James B. Eustis, Madeleine Astor, William Kissam Vanderbilt, Eugene Grace, president of Bethlehem Steel, Allan Pinkerton, and W. Averell Harriman.
Aiken is home to the University of South Carolina Aiken.
It became part of Aiken County when the county was formed in 1871.
In the late 19th century, Aiken gained fame as a wintering spot for wealthy people from the Northeast.
Thomas Hitchcock, Senior and William C. Whitney established the Aiken Winter Colony.
As of the 2010 census, its population was 429.
It developed as a lumber and mill town.
The majority of residents are African American.
Anderson is the smallest of the three primary cities that make up the Upstate region, and is nicknamed the "Electric City" and the "Friendliest City in South Carolina".
It is one of the principal cities in the Greenville-Anderson-Greer, SC Metropolitan Statistical Area, which had an estimated population of 975480 in 2023.
It is included in the larger Greenville-Spartanburg-Anderson, SC Combined Statistical Area, which had an estimated population of 1590636 in 2023.
It is just off Interstate 85 and is 120 miles (190 km) from Atlanta and 140 miles (230 km) from Charlotte.
A 38-foot tall Confederate Memorial currently resides prominently in the center of downtown Anderson.
Its total population was 2575 at the 2020 census, down from 2861 in 2010.
General aviation airfield Robert F. Swinnie Airport is 2 miles (3 km) east of its central business district.
Most of the land around the town is annexed into the city of North Myrtle Beach.
Aynor High School consistently ranks as one of the best schools in Horry County and South Carolina.

The prominent role of Beaufort and the surrounding Sea Islands during the Reconstruction era after the U S Civil War is memorialized by the Reconstruction Era National Monument, established in 2017.
The city is renowned for its scenic location and for maintaining a historic character by preservation of its antebellum architecture.
The city is also known for its military establishments, being located in close proximity to Parris Island, a U S naval hospital, and the Marine Corps Air Station Beaufort.
The city's population was 13607 at the 2020 census.
Beaufort is located on Port Royal Island, in the heart of the Sea Islands and South Carolina Lowcountry.

The communities of Antioch, Cherokee Falls, Kings Creek, Cashion Crossroads, Buffalo, and Mount Paran are located near the town.
Blacksburg is in Upstate South Carolina on the Interstate 85 corridor about 45 mi (72 km) southwest of Charlotte, North Carolina.
The town was named after Alexander Black, a railroad promoter.
The community is located near the Broad River at the county's western border, 18 miles (29 km) west of Winnsboro.
It is named for Blenheim Palace in Oxfordshire, England.
Blenheim Palace was the residence of the Duke of Marlborough, after whom Marlboro County is named.
Blenheim Ginger Ale was originally bottled in Blenheim, with the local mineral water.
During the Civil War, two thirds of the town was destroyed by fire during the Union's Bluffton Expedition on June 4, 1863.
After the Tariff of 1842, Bluffton became a hotbed of separatist sentiment, which in turn led to a protest against federal taxes called the Bluffton Movement in 1844.
It is primarily located around U S Route 278 between Hilton Head Island and Interstate 95.
Even though the movement quickly died out, it somewhat contributed to the secession movement that led to South Carolina being the first state to leave the Union.
In the Antebellum Period, Bluffton became a popular location for wealthy merchants and plantation owners.

Chapin, popularly known as the "Capital of Lake Murray", is a small lake town located at the northern tip of Lexington County, South Carolina, United States.
Lake Murray separates Chapin from the rest of Lexington County.
Chapin is located approximately 24 miles (39 km) northwest of Columbia, and many people commute there for work.
The Moon-Dominick House and Webb-Coleman House are listed on the National Register of Historic Places.
The community was named after the local Chappell family of pioneer citizens.
A post office was established in 1820, closed after a year, then reopened again in 1830.
1852 saw the arrival of the Greenville and Columbia Railroad, and the area, now known as Chappell's Depot, was a thriving community.
After the 1755 Treaty of Saluda Old Town ceded former Cherokee land to the Saluda area, Thomas Chappell settled on the north side of the Saluda River and was given permission to operate a ferry.
Thomas' son John built another bridge over the river in 1838.
A new, modern bridge was built for Highway 39 to span the river west of the town in 1931.
In 1792 Thomas built a bridge across the Saluda, but it was destroyed in 1800 and he once again operated a ferry service.
The area became known as Chappell's Ferry.
Unfortunately, a tornado on 19 February, 1884 wiped out nearly the entire town.
Charleston is the oldest and largest city in South Carolina, founded in 1670 as Charles Town.
The first shots of the American Civil War were fired at Fort Sumter in Charleston Harbor in 1861.
Charleston's historic district features one of the largest collections of 18th and 19th century architecture in the US.
The city has been repeatedly named the best city in the United States by Travel + Leisure magazine.
Rainbow Row, a series of 13 colorful Georgian row houses, is one of the most photographed spots in the city.
The College of Charleston, founded in 1770, is the oldest college in South Carolina and 13th oldest in the nation.
Charleston was a major port for the Atlantic slave trade, with nearly half of all enslaved Africans brought to America arriving through the city.
The Charlotte and South Carolina Railroad began in 1852 and operated until 1869, when it was absorbed by Charlotte, Columbia and Augusta Railroad.
The railroad was 110 miles (180 km) long and its track gauge was 5 ft (1524 mm).
The line ran between Charlotte, North Carolina, and Columbia, South Carolina.
It was the first carrier to serve Mecklenburg County, North Carolina.
It has been nicknamed "The Prettiest Town in Dixie".
The community was segregated.
Many African Americans, including the principal and teachers at Finley School, lived in East Chester.
Clearwater is located in historic Horse Creek Valley.
Clemson is adjacent to Clemson University, and is identified with it.
In 2015, the Princeton Review cited the town of Clemson as ranking #1 in the United States for "town-and-gown" relations with its resident university.
Clemson is part of the Greenville-Anderson-Greer, SC Metropolitan Statistical Area, which is also included in the Greenville-Spartanburg-Anderson, SC Combined Statistical Area.

Columbia is home to the University of South Carolina, the state's flagship public university and the largest in the state.

In 1860, the South Carolina Secession Convention took place in Columbia; delegates voted for secession, making South Carolina the first state to leave the Union in the events leading up to the Civil War.
Columbia is the site of Fort Jackson, the largest United States Army installation for Basic Combat Training.
The name of the city is often abbreviated as "Cola", leading to its nickname "Soda City".
It lies at the confluence of the Saluda River and the Broad River, which merge at Columbia to form the Congaree River.
The name "Columbia", a poetic term referring to the U.S., derives from the name of Christopher Columbus, who explored the Caribbean on behalf of the Spanish Empire.

Due to its status as a bedroom community, Edisto Beach is among the most affluent communities in the state.

Hilton Head Island, often referred to as simply Hilton Head, is a Lowcountry resort town and barrier island in Beaufort County, South Carolina, United States.
Once the island fell to Union troops, hundreds of ex-slaves flocked to Hilton Head, which is still home to many of their descendants, who are known as the Gullah (or Geechee).
The island features 12 miles (19 km) of beachfront on the Atlantic Ocean and is a popular vacation destination.
Approximately 70% of the island, including most of the tourist areas, is located inside gated communities.

However, the town maintains several public beach access points, including one for the exclusive use of town residents, who have approved several multimillion-dollar land-buying bond referendums to control commercial growth.
In 2004, an estimated 2.25 million visitors infused more than $1.5 billion into the local economy.

Johns Island is an island in Charleston County, South Carolina, United States, and is the largest island in the state of South Carolina.
It is the fourth-largest island on the US east coast, surpassed only by Long Island, Mount Desert Island and Martha's Vineyard.
Johns Island was named after Saint John Parish in Barbados by the first English colonial settlers on the island, who had come from there.
Johns Island is bordered by the Wadmalaw, Seabrook, Kiawah, Edisto, Folly, and James islands; the Stono and Kiawah rivers separate Johns Island from its border islands.

They are a relatively small American Indian tribe that has occupied the Pee Dee region for several centuries.

While today the tribe consists of just over 200 enrolled members, they were once a significant cultural and political power in the region.
Their profound influence and continual presence in the area is why the region bears the Pee Dee name.

More than 104000 people moved to the area over eight years, representing a nearly 28% growth in population.
It is the home of Newberry College, a private liberal-arts college affiliated with the Evangelical Lutheran Church in America.
The charter was adopted in 1894.
Newberry became a city in 1976, but did not report the change to the Census Bureau for more than twenty-five years.
As a result, the city was listed as a town in the 2000 census.
As of the 2020 census, the town had a population of 2096, making it the second-largest municipality in the county behind the City of Greenwood.

It lies directly across the river, and state border, from Augusta, Georgia.
As of the 2020 census, North Charleston had a population of 114852, making it the third-most populous city in the state, and the 248th-most populous city in the United States.
It was created in 1968 from four existing municipalities, and is located about 15 miles (24 km) northeast of Myrtle Beach.
It serves as one of the primary tourist destinations along the Grand Strand.
As of the 2020 census, the population was 18790.
Okatie takes its name from the nearby Okatee River, an estuary of the Port Royal Sound.
Okatie has experienced predominantly low-density residential development since the 1990s, including Sun City Hilton Head, Riverbend, and Oldfield.
This development pattern has resulted in concerns over water quality and loss of forest habitat for wildlife.
The headquarters of the Beaufort-Jasper Water and Sewer Authority are located in Okatie, as are the Beaufort-Jasper Academy for Career Excellence and John Paul II Catholic High School.
It was designated a voting precinct on March 1, 1916, by the General Assembly of the State of South Carolina.
Portions of Okatie have been annexed by Bluffton, Hardeeville and Port Royal.
South Carolina Highway 170 (also known as Okatie Highway) is generally considered to be the main route through Okatie.
Additional commercial and low intensity industrial development have also occurred, primarily in the Jasper County sections of Okatie.
Previous efforts to incorporate the community have been unsuccessful, due in part to conflicting opinions on the future of growth and development in the area.
Two historically black institutions of higher education are located in Orangeburg: Claflin University (a liberal arts college) and South Carolina State University (a public university).
Pageland is widely known for the annual Pageland Watermelon Festival that has been held in July annually since 1951.
The watermelon is an important staple in Pageland's community in history.

In 1952, Pageland adopted the title of "The Watermelon Capital of the World." Many of the town's benches and business display watermelons and Pageland's water tower features a watermelon painted on the tank.
The William Dixon Fowler House was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2012.
It was first listed as a CDP in the 2020 census with a population of 209.
Until the 1890s, Pauline was known as Stribling.
The community took the name "Pauline" when they were to name a post office and the name "Stribling" was already taken; "Pauline" was the first name of the postmaster's daughter at the time.
It is on the southern end of The Grand Strand and is one of the oldest resort areas of the US East Coast.
The island lies off the Waccamaw Neck, a long, narrow peninsula between the ocean and the river, and is connected to the mainland by two bridges, the North Causeway and the South Causeway.
Pawleys Island's population was 103 at the 2010 census, down from 138 in 2000.
The town of Pawleys Island, though, is only on the island.
The town was named after Joseph Pack.
Its population was 89 at the 2010 census, and grew to 1344 at the 2020 census.
The Pendleton Historic District, consisting of the town and its immediate surroundings, was added to the National Register of Historic Places in 1970.

Particularly notable historic buildings on the Pendleton town square include Farmer's Hall and Hunter's Store, which is currently the headquarters of the Pendleton District Historical, Recreational and Tourism Commission.
Near Pendleton are the historic plantation homes Ashtabula and Woodburn.
It was named after Andrew Pickens, an American revolutionary soldier and US Congressman for South Carolina.
Pickens changed its classification from a town to a city in 1998, but it was not reported to the Census Bureau until 2001.
It is included in the Sumter, South Carolina Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Port Royal is home to Marine Corps Recruit Depot Parris Island and United States Naval Hospital Beaufort.
It is included in the Sumter, South Carolina Metropolitan Statistical Area.

Rock Hill offers scenic riverfront views along the Catawba River and is home to numerous nature trails, restaurants, and thirty-one parks which are used for both national and local events.

Rockville is a town in Charleston County, South Carolina, United States, that was founded in 1784.

On J. G. W. De Brahm's 1757 "Map of South Carolina and a Part of Georgia," a round geographical feature labeled "Round O Savannah" is clearly visible west of the Edisto River in St. Bartholomew's Parish.
Its elevation is 36 feet (11 m).
According to tradition, the community received its name from a local Native American whose name was too long to pronounce, hence the name Round O, and painted his torso with a circular design.
The community is located on U S Route 21, 11 miles (18 km) northwest of Walterboro.

Saint George is included within the Charleston-North Charleston, SC Metropolitan Statistical Area, as defined by the U S Office of Management and Budget, and used by the U. S. Census Bureau for statistical purposes only.
St. Helena Island is a Sea Island in Beaufort County, South Carolina, United States.
The island is connected to Beaufort by U S Highway 21.
The island is renowned for its rural Lowcountry character and being a major center of African-American Gullah culture and language.
It is considered to be the geographic influence behind the children's television program Gullah Gullah Island.
The town holds an annual Purple Martin festival in April which includes food, music, cars, and more.
St. Matthews is part of the Columbia, South Carolina Metropolitan Statistical Area.
Salley is known for hosting the Chitlin Strut, a town-wide festival, every November.
The Salters Plantation House was listed on the National Register of Historic Places in 2000.
Charleston, South Carolina and Myrtle Beach, South Carolina are within driving distance of Salters making for an enjoyable day trip to either.

Nearby towns include Kingstree, Greeleyville, and Lane.
Salters is the location of Federal Correctional Institution, Williamsburg.

Sangaree has a public library, a branch of the Berkeley County Library System.

The region has been rural, with a primarily agricultural economy typical of Orangeburg County, but is now known primarily for its several golf courses in proximity to Lake Marion, Santee State Park and other Lake Marion attractions.
Interstate 95 connects its attractions easily with tourists traveling by automobile.
Lake Marion is a man-made hydroelectric reservoir, which at 110000 acres (450 km2, 173 sq mi) is one of the fifty largest lakes in the country.
It has become a resort town of note located centrally north-south along the Atlantic Seaboard of South Carolina.
I-95 crosses a narrow arm of the lake into the town lands, along a causeway.
The Lake Marion High School & Technology Center is located in the town.
The town has been undergoing economic and population growth, and development as rural niches are supplanted by bedroom communities.
Construction of the Santee Cooper Regional Water System can provide millions of gallons of potable water per day to the surrounding five counties centered about Santee.
The system was coordinated by the U S Department of Agriculture and funded by the Army Corps of Engineers, USEPA, and the South Carolina Department of Commerce.
The plant was completed and operational as of June 1, 2008.
Seabrook Island, formerly known as Simmons Island, is a barrier island in Charleston County, South Carolina, United States.
Seneca was named for the nearby Cherokee town of Isunigu, which English colonists knew as "Seneca Town".

The unemployment rate is about 3.1 percent, according to 2023 census estimates.

In the 2020 census, the population of Society Hill was 438, down from 563 in 2010, 700 in 2000 and 848 in 1980.
Society Hill was originally settled in the 18th century by a colony of Baptists, who named the community after their "St. David's Society," the predecessor to the Society Hill Library Society.

Spartanburg is the home of Wofford College, Converse University, Spartanburg Community College, and Edward Via College of Osteopathic Medicine and the area is home to USC Upstate, Sherman College of Chiropractic and Spartanburg Methodist College.

Sullivan's Island, historically known as O'Sullivan's Island, is a town and island in Charleston County, South Carolina, United States, at the entrance to Charleston Harbor, with a population of 1791 at the 2010 census, and 1891 people in 2020.
Per the 2020 census, the population was 814.
It lies approximately five miles from the Ashley River.
The city makes up the Sumter, SC Metropolitan Statistical Area.

Sumter County, along with Clarendon and Lee counties, form the core of Sumter–Lee–Clarendon tri-county (or East Midlands) area of South Carolina that includes three counties straddling the border of the Sandhills (or Midlands), Pee Dee, and Lowcountry regions.
Its nickname is "The Family Beach".
It is considered a part of the Grand Strand.
On April 5, 2022, the town was hit by an EF3 tornado, although it had weakened to EF1 strength by the time it moved through town and only minor damage occurred.

Tega Cay is located on a peninsula along Lake Wylie, twenty miles south of Charlotte.

It is a suburb of Charlotte, North Carolina.

Travelers Rest, the northernmost city in Greenville County, is located 10 miles north of Greenville and around 20 miles south of the North Carolina border.
Initially built as a reprieve for his oxen and coach herd, the family eventually did yoke and axle repair for settlers headed out on the Oregon Trail.

Varnville forms a twin town with Hampton, the county seat; the two towns often share civic and cultural events.
It is named for American Civil War general and South Carolina governor Wade Hampton.

Designated in 1868 as the county seat, it lies within the area of the Blue Ridge Escarpment, an area of transition between mountains and piedmont, and contains numerous waterfalls.

Walterboro is located 48 miles (77 km) west of Charleston and is located near the ACE Basin region in the South Carolina Lowcountry.

Wedgefield was so named because its location was likened to a "wedge" into the High Hills of Santee.

West Ashley, or more formally, west of the Ashley, is one of the six distinct areas of the city proper of Charleston, South Carolina.

Before Westville got its name, it was known only as the West Section.
In 1888, resident John C. West applied for the establishment of a post office and became the first postmaster.
This post office officially changed its name to Westville in 1890.
Westville is located on U S Route 521, 16 miles north of Camden.

Located in the South Carolina Lowcountry, Yemassee is divided by the county line between Hampton and Beaufort counties along the roadbed of the CSX railroad.
Most of the town's population lies within Hampton County.
Yemassee hosts one of the few commercial breeding facilities of non-human primates in the entire United States, Alpha Genesis, which serves as a major employer for the town.
The Frank Lloyd Wright-designed Auldbrass Plantation house and outbuildings lie just outside the town limits of Yemassee.
The town is 44 miles (71 km) north of Savannah, Georgia, and 54 miles (87 km) west of Charleston, South Carolina.
York is located approximately 27 miles (43 km) southwest of Charlotte, North Carolina and 13 miles (21 km) west of Rock Hill, South Carolina.
